awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Financial Market Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an interdisciplinary project involving computer science and economics. The big data problem to be addressed concerns how to analyze and understand financial trading, and its effects on the stock market. The project introduces new behavioral models of financial trading and applies big data techniques to implement them.  The project will foster research on the financial ecosystem of machine-machine and machine-human interactions by bringing financial economists and data scientists together in a series of workshops.

The PIs will work with the National Center for Supercomputing and develop a new and more accurate taxonomy of trading frequencies by categorizing high frequency traders (HFT), buy-side algorithmic traders (BAT) and human traders using two proprietary high frequency datasets. The workshops will foster research on the implications of the new financial ecosystem for the overall financial system and the economy in general, as well as creating new metrics and data for the discipline of finance in economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, in collaboration with NSF Grant 18-38183, has successfully established big data in finance as a recognized and thriving field through interdisciplinary efforts between the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) and the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA). The initiative supported innovative research on machine-machine and machine-human interactions in trading and fostered collaboration between financial economists and experts in high-performance computing (HPC) and big data through a series of influential conferences.

Interdisciplinary Collaboration and Conferences

Over the past six years, the grant supported annual NBER Summer and Winter Big Data conferences, which have become a hub for interdisciplinary collaboration in the field of big data in finance. These events provided a platform for scholars to present cutting-edge research, exchange ideas, and explore the intersection of finance, high-performance computing, and big data. Staff from the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) supported numerous supercomputing requests emerging from research presented at these conferences, enabling scholars to tackle complex financial problems with unprecedented computational power.

To enhance accessibility and inclusivity, the conferences were live-streamed on YouTube, engaging a global audience and fostering a vibrant academic and professional community. This outreach bridged the gap between finance and technology. Additionally, the Review of Financial Studies (RFS), a top-tier finance journal, published two special issues featuring conference papers, documenting six years of progress and innovation in the field.

Research and Impact on Public Policy

Research supported by this grant has had a profound impact on public policy. On September 18, 2024, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) unanimously adopted a rule to reduce transaction costs for U.S. investors, extensively citing grant-supported research. Key contributions include:

  • Reducing Tick Size: The smallest price change (tick size) for stocks above $1 was reduced from 1 cent to 0.5 cents under certain conditions, potentially cutting transaction costs by up to 50% for investors. Research by Li, Wang, and Ye (2021) and Li and Ye (2024) informed this change.
  • Reducing Lot Size: The minimum lot size for most U.S. stocks is 100 shares. For example, if a stock’s best ask price is $2000 and the best bid price is $1998, these quotes apply to a minimum of 100 shares. Research by Li and Ye (2024) shows that market makers face lower adverse selection risks for smaller lot sizes (e.g., 10 shares), leading to better prices. Their results provide the economic foundation for the new rule, which aims to reduce lot sizes for stocks priced above $250. This policy change will reduce the transaction costs for high-priced stocks.
  • Reducing Exchange Fees: Under Regulation NMS, the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO) routes orders to the exchange offering the best gross price, disregarding exchange fees. Li, Ye, and Zheng (2023) found that this approach results in 62% of orders being routed to exchanges with worse net prices once fees are accounted for. The revised rule lowers exchange fee caps from 0.3 cents to 0.1 cents per share, addressing fee distortions in stock trading. This policy change also has the potential to significantly reduce total transaction costs when adjusted for fees.

In addition, research supported by the grant informs ongoing policy debates. Over the past four decades, there has been a secular increase in share buybacks relative to dividends, with the total annual amount of share buybacks now exceeding $1 trillion. Li, Ye, and Zheng (2024) identify price ceilings and reduced market-structure frictions as two important drivers of this trend. These economic factors play a significant role in shaping the ongoing policy discussion on whether and how regulators should address share buybacks.

Defining the Field of Big Data in Finance

At the project’s inception, the concept of big data in finance was neither clearly defined nor widely recognized. The classical three Vs definition of big data—volume, velocity, and variety—originated in engineering and computer science but did not fully address finance-specific challenges and opportunities. Financial economists primarily focus on applying tools to answer pressing economic questions, distinguishing their approach from engineers and statisticians who develop these tools.

Grant-supported conferences introduced a three-pronged framework for big data in finance: large size, high dimension, and complex structure (see Goldstein, Spatt, and Ye (2021, 2024) for details). While this framework may evolve, it provides a foundational starting point for future research and advancements in the field.

Conclusion

This project has made significant strides in advancing the field of big data in finance, cultivating a new generation of researchers adept at applying supercomputing techniques to address complex financial challenges. The conferences funded by this grant have emerged as prestigious platforms for interdisciplinary collaboration, bringing together leading scholars from finance, economics, and high-performance computing. Moreover, the research supported by this grant has influenced public policy by lowering transaction costs for American investors.
